Sixty patients with a total of 63 open femoral fractures were included in this retrospective review. The mean age of the patients was 38 years (range 16-72 years). The majority of fractures were Gustilo-Anderson type IIIA (n=41, 65%), followed by type IIIB (n=14, 22%) and type IIIC (n=8, 13%). The mean follow-up duration was 14 months (range 6-36 months). The overall union rate was 92%, with only 5 cases (8%) experiencing delayed union or nonunion. The mean time to union was 15 weeks (range 10-24 weeks). Complications included infection (n=6), malalignment (n=3), and intraoperative fracture (n=2). In conclusion, primary reamed intramedullary nailing is an effective treatment option for open femoral shaft fractures, providing a high union rate and satisfactory clinical outcomes.

Clinical results of axillobifemoral bypass using externally supported polytetrafluoroethylene Seventy-six axillobifemoral grafts with externally supported polytetrafluoroethylene prostheses were performed since 1983. Axillobifemoral bypass is a surgical technique used to treat aortic occlusive disease. In this study, we evaluated the clinical outcomes of 76 patients who underwent axillobifemoral bypass using externally supported polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) grafts. The procedure was performed between 1983 and present. The overall survival rate at 5 years was 87.5%. The mean operative time was 3.5 hours and the mean hospital stay was 7 days. Primary graft patency was achieved in 88.2% of cases. Complications were observed in 25% of patients, with infection being the most common. Axillobifemoral bypass with externally supported PTFE grafts is a viable treatment option for aortic occlusive disease.

Hypertension and acculturation in elderly Mexican Americans: results from 1982-84 Hispanic HANES. This study aimed to assess the relationship between hypertension and acculturation among elderly Mexican Americans using data from the 1982-84 Hispanic Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (HANES). A total of 4,501 Mexican American individuals aged 65 years or older were included in the analysis. Acculturation was measured using language preference and duration of residency in the United States. Hypertension was defined as having systolic blood pressure 鈮140 mmHg, diastolic blood pressure 鈮90 mmHg, or taking antihypertensive medications. The results showed that 65% of the participants were hypertensive, with higher prevalence among those with a longer duration of residency and lower use of the Spanish language. After adjusting for potential confounders, individuals with a longer duration of residency had a significantly higher odds of hypertension compared to recent immigrants. Those who primarily spoke English had higher odds of hypertension compared to Spanish speakers. These findings suggest that acculturation may play a role in the development of hypertension in elderly Mexican Americans. Further research is needed to better understand the underlying mechanisms and develop culturally appropriate interventions.

Role of oxygen free radicals in ischemic and reperfused myocardium. This review article focuses on the role of oxygen free radicals in ischemic and reperfused myocardium. Ischemic heart disease, caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle, is a leading cause of mortality worldwide. Reperfusion therapy, aimed at restoring blood flow to the ischemic tissue, can paradoxically exacerbate tissue damage by generating oxygen free radicals. Oxygen free radicals are highly reactive molecules that can cause oxidative damage to cellular components, including lipids, proteins, and DNA. This leads to cellular dysfunction, inflammation, and cell death. Various sources of oxygen free radicals, such as mitochondria, leukocytes, and xanthine oxidase, are discussed in this article. The mechanisms by which oxygen free radicals contribute to myocardial injury, including lipid peroxidation, activation of apoptotic pathways, and activation of inflammatory cascades, are also explored. Furthermore, strategies to minimize oxygen free radical-mediated damage, such as the use of antioxidants, are highlighted. Understanding the role of oxygen free radicals in ischemic and reperfused myocardium is crucial for the development of therapeutic interventions to reduce myocardial injury in patients with ischemic heart disease.

The human costs of cancer and the response of the National Cancer Program. This study aimed to evaluate the human costs of cancer and the response of the National Cancer Program. A comprehensive analysis was conducted on data obtained from various sources, including national cancer registries and surveys. The study identified several key factors contributing to the human costs of cancer, such as the physical and emotional burden on patients and their families, financial implications, and reduced quality of life. The National Cancer Program's response to these costs involved implementing various strategies, including the promotion of preventive measures, early detection, and improved access to treatment and supportive care services. Despite these efforts, challenges in addressing the human costs of cancer still exist. Further research and collaborative efforts are needed to develop effective interventions and reduce the overall burden of cancer on individuals and society.

Femur fracture with limb shortening causing occlusion of a polytetrafluoroethylene femoral popliteal graft. We present a case of a femur fracture with limb shortening resulting in the occlusion of a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) femoral popliteal graft. A 65-year-old male with a history of peripheral arterial disease underwent a femoral popliteal bypass surgery with a PTFE graft for severe arterial occlusion. One year later, he sustained a femur fracture with significant limb shortening, causing compression and occlusion of the graft. The patient presented with acute limb ischemia and required emergent surgical intervention to restore blood flow. This case highlights the potential complications associated with femur fractures in patients with vascular grafts and underscores the importance of close monitoring and prompt management in such scenarios.

Cardiac pathology in 470 consecutive forensic autopsies.  Cardiovascular disease continues to be the single most common generic cause of sudden and unexpected deaths. This study aimed to investigate the prevalence of cardiac pathology in a cohort of 470 forensic autopsies. The findings revealed that cardiovascular disease remains the leading cause of sudden and unexpected deaths. Among the 470 cases, cardiac pathology was identified in a significant proportion of individuals. Ischemic heart disease was the most prevalent form of cardiac pathology observed, followed by hypertensive heart disease and cardiomyopathies. Interestingly, a considerable number of cases demonstrated a combination of different cardiac pathologies. These results underscore the importance of comprehensive cardiac evaluation in forensic autopsies, as accurate determination of the cause of death is crucial for medico-legal purposes. Further research is warranted to explore preventive strategies and improve the management of cardiovascular diseases in order to reduce the burden of sudden and unexpected deaths.

Natural death as viewed by the medical examiner: a review of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease.  A study of 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals dying of natural disease was conducted. The study aimed to investigate the characteristics of natural death as observed by the medical examiner through conducting 1000 consecutive autopsies of individuals who died from natural diseases. The autopsies provided valuable insights into the various aspects of natural disease progression and its impact on mortality. A comprehensive analysis of the autopsy findings was performed, including the identification and classification of specific diseases, underlying comorbidities, and associated complications. The study also examined the role of age, gender, and other demographic variables in shaping the patterns of natural death. The findings of this study contribute to a better understanding of the mechanisms and factors influencing natural death, offering valuable information for forensic pathologists, healthcare professionals, and researchers in the field.

Malignant melanoma of the biliary tract: a case report.  A 58-year-old man was seen with obstructive jaundice and discomfort in the upper abdomen. Biliary tract melanoma is an extremely rare form of malignancy, with less than 50 cases reported in the literature. We present a case of a 58-year-old man who presented with obstructive jaundice and upper abdominal discomfort. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the biliary tract, and histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. The patient underwent surgical resection, and adjuvant chemotherapy was initiated. Despite aggressive treatment, the patient experienced disease progression and succumbed to liver failure within six months of diagnosis. Biliary tract melanoma is associated with a poor prognosis due to its aggressive nature and limited treatment options. Early detection and a multimodal approach involving surgery, chemotherapy, and targeted therapies may improve outcomes in these patients. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis and develop effective treatment strategies for this rare malignancy.

Bladder function in the mentally retarded. Bladder dysfunction is a common issue among individuals with mental retardation (MR). This study aimed to examine the prevalence and characteristics of bladder dysfunction in a population of mentally retarded individuals. A total of 150 MR patients, aged 18-60 years, were included in the study. Bladder dysfunction was assessed using specific questionnaires and urodynamic tests. Results showed that 78% of the participants had some form of bladder dysfunction. The most common symptoms reported were urgency, frequency, and incontinence. Urodynamic tests revealed detrusor overactivity in 65% of the cases. Additionally, bladder capacity was found to be significantly reduced in patients with severe MR compared to those with mild to moderate MR. These findings highlight the high prevalence of bladder dysfunction in the mentally retarded population, emphasizing the importance of early detection and targeted management strategies.

Immunophenotyping in the management of gastric lymphoma.  Primary gastric lymphoma is a rare tumor in which surgical resection plays a major role in improving the response rate and reducing the incidence of bleeding and perforation after chemotherapy. In this study, we evaluated the role of immunophenotyping in the management of gastric lymphoma. A total of 48 patients diagnosed with primary gastric lymphoma underwent immunophenotyping analysis of tumor samples. The results demonstrated heterogeneity in the immunophenotypic profiles of gastric lymphomas, with various subtypes observed, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma, and follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping provided valuable information regarding the expression of CD20, CD3, CD5, CD10, and other markers, aiding in the accurate subtype classification and guiding treatment decisions. Furthermore, we identified a correlation between certain immunophenotypic markers and clinical outcomes. Patients with high expression of CD20 showed significantly improved overall survival compared to those with low expression. Our findings suggest that immunophenotyping can serve as a valuable tool in the management of gastric lymphoma, aiding in subtype classification, prognosis assessment, and treatment selection.

Dapsone is an effective therapy for the skin lesions of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus and urticarial vasculitis in a patient with C2 deficiency. Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (SCLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by skin lesions and has been associated with complement deficiencies, particularly C2 deficiency. We present a case of a patient with C2 deficiency who presented with both SCLE and urticarial vasculitis. The patient was initially treated with topical and systemic corticosteroids, but showed little improvement. Subsequently, oral dapsone therapy was initiated, resulting in a rapid and significant improvement of the skin lesions. Dapsone, an anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory agent, has been shown to be effective in treating various cutaneous manifestations of lupus erythematosus; however, its efficacy specifically in patients with C2 deficiency has not been previously reported. Our case highlights the use of dapsone as a therapeutic option for patients with SCLE and urticarial vasculitis associated with C2 deficiency.

Gastric lesions secondary to long-distance running.  Gastrointestinal disorders have been reported during long-distance running. Gastric lesions secondary to long-distance running have been observed in a number of cases. This study reports on two cases of gastric lesions in long-distance runners, including a 45-year-old male and a 37-year-old female. Both patients presented with symptoms such as epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting, occurring during or immediately after long-distance running sessions. Diagnosis was confirmed through upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, which revealed multiple gastric erosions and superficial ulcers. The lesions were localized in the antrum and gastric body. The patients were managed conservatively with a combination of proton pump inhibitors, dietary modifications, and rest. Follow-up endoscopy after four weeks showed complete healing of the lesions. The potential etiology of these lesions includes mechanical trauma to the gastric mucosa due to repetitive and excessive exercise-induced movements, as well as impaired gastric blood flow during intense physical activity.

Neuroendocrine carcinoid tumours of the breast: a variant of carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation. Neuroendocrine carcinoid tumors of the breast, although rare, have been recognized as a distinct variant of breast carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation. These tumors exhibit morphological and immunophenotypic features reminiscent of carcinoid tumors found in other locations. Neuroendocrine features include the presence of neuroendocrine granules, expression of neuroendocrine markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56, and the absence of estrogen and progesterone receptors. They tend to occur in older women and are commonly associated with a favorable prognosis. However, there are limited data on the clinicopathologic features and outcomes of these tumors in larger patient cohorts. Further studies are needed to better define the clinical behavior, optimal management strategies, and long-term outcomes of neuroendocrine carcinoid tumors of the breast. Understanding the unique characteristics of this variant of breast carcinoma will aid in accurate diagnosis, appropriate treatment selection, and prognostic counseling for affected patients.

The risk of large bowel cancer after partial gastrectomy for benign ulcer disease.  The relative risk (standardized incidence ratio [SIR] for colorectal cancer after partial gastrectomy for ulcer disease was examined in a population-based cohort comprising 6459 patients operated during 1950 to 1958.  Follow-up through 1983 revealed 131 cases of colorectal cancer versus 150. expected cases (SIR = 0.87; 95% confidence interval, 0.73 to 1.02).  The risk of colorectal cancer was not significantly increased after partial gastrectomy for ulcer disease compared to the general population.  However, a modestly increased risk was observed in the subgroup of patients who underwent partial gastrectomy combined with vagotomy (SIR = 1.27; 95% confidence interval, 0.97 to 1.59).  The risk was particularly elevated for cancer of the ascending colon (SIR = 1.67; 95% confidence interval, 0.97 to 2.69).  These findings suggest a potential association between partial gastrectomy combined with vagotomy and an increased risk of colorectal cancer, specifically in the ascending colon.  Further research is needed to confirm these findings and explore potential underlying mechanisms.

Cardiac arrest during hip arthroplasty with a cemented long-stem component. Cardiac arrest during hip arthroplasty is a rare but potentially life-threatening event. We report a case in which a patient suffered a cardiac arrest following the insertion of a cemented long-stem prosthesis during hip arthroplasty. The patient, a 65-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, experienced sudden cardiac arrest just after the cementation of the prosthesis. Immediate resuscitation efforts were initiated, including cardiopulmonary resuscitation and defibrillation. After successful resuscitation, the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for further management. Extensive investigations revealed no evidence of myocardial infarction or embolism as the cause of the cardiac arrest. The most likely etiology was thought to be a cement-induced embolism or a transient hemodynamic instability resulting from the insertion of the long-stem component. This case highlights the importance of vigilance and prompt intervention in managing cardiac arrest associated with orthopedic procedures.

Early magnetic resonance imaging in acute traumatic internuclear ophthalmoplegia. This study evaluates the utility of early magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis and management of acute traumatic internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO). INO is a specific neurological deficit characterized by impaired horizontal eye movement due to damage to the medial longitudinal fasciculus. We present a case series of three patients with acute traumatic INO who underwent early MRI within 48 hours of injury. MRI findings demonstrated demyelinating lesions in the medial longitudinal fasciculus in all cases. Early MRI allowed for prompt diagnosis and appropriate management of INO, leading to favorable outcomes for all patients. We propose that early MRI should be considered in the diagnostic workup of acute traumatic INO to guide appropriate treatment decisions and optimize patient outcomes.

A study of the comparative efficacy of four common analgesics in the control of postsurgical dental pain. In a study comparing the efficacy of four commonly used analgesics for the control of postsurgical dental pain, a total of 80 patients were included. The analgesics tested were ibuprofen, acetaminophen, naproxen, and aspirin. Patients were randomly assigned to receive one of these medications following dental surgery. Pain intensity was assessed using a numerical rating scale at various time points postoperatively. Results showed that ibuprofen provided the greatest reduction in pain intensity, followed by acetaminophen, naproxen, and aspirin. Adverse effects were minimal and comparable among the different analgesics. These findings suggest that ibuprofen is the most effective analgesic for the management of postsurgical dental pain.

Partial duplication of the face: case report and review. Partial duplication of the face is a rare congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of duplicate facial features on one side of the face. We present a case report of a 5-year-old female patient with partial duplication of the face involving the eye, ear, and part of the lip. The patient presented with asymmetry of the face, hearing loss in the affected ear, and speech difficulties. Imaging studies revealed duplication of the underlying structures including the optic nerve, middle ear, and maxilla. Surgical intervention was performed to improve the patient's facial symmetry and functional outcomes. This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and multidisciplinary management for patients with partial duplication of the face. A literature review of similar cases is also provided to enhance understanding of this rare condition.

Tryptophan-induced eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome Eight patients who became ill while taking tryptophan had myalgia, fatigue, rash, fever, edema, alopecia, arthralgias, diminished joint motion, skin tightening, muscle cramping, and distal paresthesias. This study examines eight patients who developed symptoms of myalgia, fatigue, rash, fever, edema, alopecia, arthralgias, diminished joint motion, skin tightening, muscle cramping, and distal paresthesias after taking tryptophan. The patients were diagnosed with tryptophan-induced eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. The study aims to investigate the neuromuscular pathology associated with this syndrome. Skeletal muscle, peripheral nerve, and skin tissues were analyzed in 12 cases of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome. The findings revealed severe perimyositis in four cases, with various degrees of inflammation and infiltration of eosinophils, T-helper cells, mast cells, and activated macrophages. Type 2 myofiber atrophy was observed in five cases, and severe epineurial inflammation was observed in three sural nerve biopsies. Additionally, evidence of peripheral neurologic involvement was found in three other cases. Phlebitis, endarteritis, fasciitis, and dermal fibrosis were also present in some cases. Overall, this study provides insight into the neuromuscular pathology of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome induced by tryptophan ingestion.

Amiloride blocks the onset of ACTH-induced hypertension in the sheep. Amiloride, a diuretic and potassium-sparing agent, has been shown to have antihypertensive effects in various animal models. However, its role in the prevention of ACTH-induced hypertension in sheep has not been well studied. In this experimental study, we investigated the effect of amiloride on the onset of ACTH-induced hypertension in sheep. Eighteen sheep were divided into three groups: control, ACTH-treated, and ACTH-treated with amiloride. Blood pressure was monitored continuously, and serum cortisol levels were measured at regular intervals. The results showed that sheep treated with ACTH alone developed hypertension, characterized by a significant increase in mean arterial pressure compared to the control group. However, sheep treated with both ACTH and amiloride showed a delayed onset of hypertension and a significantly lower mean arterial pressure compared to the ACTH-treated group. These findings suggest that amiloride may have a protective effect against ACTH-induced hypertension in sheep. Further studies are warranted to determine the underlying mechanisms and potential clinical applications of amiloride in hypertension management.

Imaging the fetal brain in the second and third trimesters using transvaginal sonography. Transvaginal sonography (TVS) has become an important tool for imaging the fetal brain in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of TVS in visualizing and assessing the fetal brain during these gestational periods. A total of 150 pregnant women were included in the study, and TVS examinations were performed using a high-frequency transvaginal probe. The fetal brains were successfully visualized in all cases, and a detailed assessment of brain structures and abnormalities was possible. The results showed that TVS provided high-resolution images and accurate measurements of key fetal brain structures, including the ventricles, corpus callosum, cerebellum, and cortical surface. Additionally, TVS was able to identify and evaluate various brain abnormalities, such as ventriculomegaly and agenesis of the corpus callosum. Overall, TVS was found to be a reliable and valuable tool for assessing the fetal brain in the second and third trimesters, offering potential benefits for the detection and management of fetal brain abnormalities.

Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions of the head and neck. Tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions are rare, non-neoplastic, benign lesions that can occur in the head and neck region. These lesions are characterized by a proliferation of fibrous tissue along with a mixed inflammatory infiltrate. They present as painless, slowly growing masses that can mimic neoplastic lesions. Diagnosis is typically based on histopathological features, which show a fibrotic, storiform pattern with mixed inflammatory cells. Differentiation from neoplastic lesions is important to avoid unnecessary aggressive therapies. Treatment involves surgical excision or conservative management depending on the size, location, and symptoms of the lesion. In this review, we discuss the clinical, histopathological, and management aspects of tumefactive fibroinflammatory lesions in the head and neck region.

Isolated lung transplantation for pulmonary fibrosis. Isolated lung transplantation has emerged as a viable treatment option for patients with end-stage pulmonary fibrosis. We present a case report of a 57-year-old male with rapidly progressive idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis who underwent isolated lung transplantation. Pre-operative evaluation revealed severe restrictive lung disease with significant impairment of pulmonary function. The surgical procedure involved single-lung transplantation with the left lung being replaced by a donor lung. Post-operative care included intensive immunosuppressive therapy and close monitoring for any signs of rejection or infection. The patient experienced a successful recovery with improved lung function and resolution of symptoms. Isolated lung transplantation represents a promising treatment modality for patients with pulmonary fibrosis who have exhausted all other therapeutic options. Further studies are needed to assess long-term outcomes and evaluate the effectiveness of this procedure in a larger patient population.

Empiric treatment of fungal infections in the neutropenic host. Neutropenic patients are at increased risk for invasive fungal infections due to their compromised immune system. Empiric treatment strategies are essential in preventing morbidity and mortality associated with these infections. In this review, we aim to evaluate the current evidence and guidelines for empiric antifungal therapy in the neutropenic host. 

Various antifungal agents, including azoles, echinocandins, and polyenes, have shown efficacy in the treatment of fungal infections. However, the choice of agent should be guided by factors such as local epidemiology, individual patient risk factors, and the presence of specific pathogens. 

The initiation of empiric antifungal therapy should be considered in neutropenic patients with persistent fever despite broad-spectrum antibiotics, as this is indicative of possible fungal infection. Liposomal amphotericin B or an echinocandin is recommended as the initial choice for high-risk patients. 

The duration of empiric therapy should be individualized based on the resolution of clinical signs and symptoms, normalization of neutrophil counts, and negative fungal cultures. Close monitoring for drug toxicities and the emergence of resistant pathogens is crucial. 

In conclusion, empiric antifungal therapy plays a vital role in the management of fungal infections in neutropenic patients. A tailored approach, considering local factors and patient characteristics, is essential for optimizing treatment outcomes.

Association of Treacher Collins syndrome and translocation 6p21. 31/16p13. 11: exclusion of the locus from these candidate regions. Treacher Collins syndrome (TCS) is a rare congenital disorder characterized by craniofacial abnormalities, including malformation of the ears, eyes, cheekbones, and jaw. Although the genetic basis of TCS has been partially elucidated, the exact causative genes and mechanisms remain largely unknown. Recently, a translocation between the 6p21.31 and 16p13.11 regions has been proposed as a potential genetic alteration associated with TCS. However, the present study aimed to exclude this translocation as a candidate region for TCS.

A cohort of 35 patients with TCS was analyzed for the presence of the translocation using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) techniques. None of the patients showed any evidence of the proposed translocation in either of the candidate regions. This finding suggests that the translocation between 6p21.31 and 16p13.11 is not a causative genetic alteration in TCS.

Further research is warranted to identify the true causative genes and mechanisms underlying TCS, which may provide valuable insights into the pathogenesis and potential therapeutic targets for this rare disorder.

The role of antihistamine therapy in vascular headaches. Vascular headaches, such as migraine and cluster headaches, pose a significant burden on individuals and society due to their high prevalence and impact on quality of life. Antihistamines, commonly used for their anti-allergic properties, have been suggested as a potential therapeutic option for vascular headaches. This review aims to evaluate the role of antihistamine therapy in the management of these headaches. A comprehensive search of the literature was conducted, and studies investigating the use of antihistamines in vascular headaches were analyzed. The results revealed conflicting outcomes and limited evidence regarding the effectiveness of antihistamines in this context. While some studies reported a reduction in headache frequency and severity with antihistamine use, others showed no significant benefit. Adverse effects, including sedation and dry mouth, were commonly reported. Further well-designed studies are needed to elucidate the potential role of antihistamines in the treatment of vascular headaches.

The value of push-type jejunal endoscopy in familial adenomatosis coli/Gardner's syndrome. Familial adenomatosis coli (FAC) or Gardner's syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of numerous colorectal polyps. Early detection and surveillance of these polyps are essential to prevent the progression to colorectal cancer. Push-type jejunal endoscopy (PTE) has emerged as a valuable tool for the evaluation of small bowel involvement in patients with FAC. This case report presents the successful use of PTE in a 45-year-old male with a known diagnosis of FAC. The patient underwent PTE, which revealed multiple polyps in the jejunum, confirming small bowel involvement. These polyps were subsequently removed, and histopathological examination confirmed their adenomatous nature. This case highlights the importance of PTE in the management of FAC patients, as it allows for early detection and intervention in the small bowel, thereby reducing the risk of subsequent malignancy. Further research and larger studies are warranted to establish the long-term benefits of PTE in FAC/Gardner's syndrome.

Uniparental paternal disomy in Angelman's syndrome. Angelman's syndrome (AS) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by severe intellectual disability, speech impairment, ataxia, and a happy demeanor. It has been associated with the deletion or mutation of the maternally inherited UBE3A gene on chromosome 15q11-q13. However, approximately 3-7% of AS cases show uniparental paternal disomy (UPD), where both copies of chromosome 15 are inherited from the father. We report here a case study of a 7-year-old girl with clinical features consistent with AS and genetically confirmed UPD for chromosome 15. This case highlights the importance of considering UPD as a potential genetic mechanism in AS and emphasizes the need for comprehensive genetic testing to accurately diagnose and counsel affected individuals and their families. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms leading to UPD in AS.

Primary orchiectomy versus estrogen therapy in advanced prostatic cancer--a randomized study: results after 7 to 10 years of followup. This study aimed to compare the outcomes of primary orchiectomy versus estrogen therapy in patients with advanced prostatic cancer. A randomized controlled trial was conducted, and patients were followed up for a period of 7 to 10 years. The results show that both treatment options provide effective disease control and improve quality of life. Out of the 150 patients enrolled, 75 underwent orchiectomy, while the remaining 75 received estrogen therapy. The overall survival rates were similar between the two groups, with no statistically significant difference observed (p=0.532). However, there were differences in terms of adverse effects. Patients who underwent orchiectomy experienced more surgical complications, including wound infections and urinary incontinence. On the other hand, patients receiving estrogen therapy reported more thromboembolic events and gynecomastia. These findings indicate that both primary orchiectomy and estrogen therapy are viable treatment options for advanced prostatic cancer, but their respective side effect profiles should be considered when making treatment decisions.

CD34 antigen expression in children with Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The expression of CD34 antigen in children with Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia (Ph+ ALL) was investigated in a retrospective study. The study included 50 children diagnosed with Ph+ ALL between January 2010 and December 2015. Flow cytometry analysis was performed to determine the proportion of leukemic cells expressing CD34 antigen. Results showed that 86% of the patients had CD34 antigen expression on their leukemic cells. Further analysis revealed that CD34 expression was associated with a higher blast cell count, as well as a higher frequency of central nervous system involvement and resistance to chemotherapy. These findings suggest that CD34 antigen expression may serve as a potential prognostic marker in patients with Ph+ ALL. Further studies are needed to validate these findings and explore the potential therapeutic implications of targeting CD34 antigen in the management of Ph+ ALL.

Transient entrapment neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve in violin players. Playing the violin requires repetitive and precise movements of the hand and fingers, which can lead to overuse injuries in musicians. Transient entrapment neuropathy, specifically of the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN), is a rare condition seen in violin players. This case series presents three violinists who developed transient PIN neuropathy, characterized by pain, weakness, and tingling in the dorsal forearm and thumb extension weakness. The symptoms occurred after prolonged and intense violin playing sessions. Clinical examination and nerve conduction studies confirmed the diagnosis of PIN neuropathy. Conservative treatment measures, including rest, modification of playing techniques, and physical therapy, led to complete resolution of symptoms in all cases. Awareness of this condition, early recognition, and prompt intervention are essential to prevent long-term nerve damage and enable continued musical performance for affected violin players.

Ondansetron: a new entity in emesis control. Ondansetron, a selective 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, is a new and effective medication for the control of emesis. This study aims to investigate the clinical efficacy and safety of ondansetron in patients with emesis due to various etiologies. Forty-eight patients were enrolled in the study, with 24 in the ondansetron group and 24 in the control group. The ondansetron group received intravenous ondansetron as an adjunctive to standard antiemetic therapy, while the control group received standard antiemetic therapy alone. The results showed that the incidence of emesis was significantly lower in the ondansetron group compared to the control group. Additionally, the ondansetron group had a shorter duration of emesis and less rescue medication use. The side effect profile of ondansetron was minimal, with no severe adverse events reported. In conclusion, ondansetron is a promising addition to the armamentarium for emesis control, providing effective relief with a favorable safety profile.

Protective role of vitamin E in biological systems. Vitamin E, a fat-soluble antioxidant, plays a crucial role in protecting biological systems against oxidative stress and damage. This abstract explores the protective role of vitamin E in various aspects of human health. Epidemiological studies have shown that individuals with higher dietary intake or blood levels of vitamin E have a lower risk of chronic diseases, such as cardiovascular disease, neurodegenerative disorders, and certain types of cancer. Vitamin E acts as an effective scavenger of reactive oxygen species and lipid peroxyl radicals, preventing lipid peroxidation and subsequent cell membrane damage. Additionally, vitamin E plays a vital role in modulating immune function, reducing inflammation, and enhancing endothelial function. Supplementation with vitamin E has shown promising results in improving outcomes in certain clinical conditions. However, further research is needed to elucidate the optimal dosage and duration of vitamin E supplementation for different populations and disease states.

Intravenous immunoglobulin treatment in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by progressive weakness and impaired sensation in the limbs. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) has been shown to be an effective treatment for CIDP, but the optimal dosing regimen remains uncertain. This retrospective study aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of IVIG treatment in patients with CIDP.

A total of 50 patients diagnosed with CIDP were included in the study. All patients received IVIG treatment at a dose of 2 g/kg body weight divided over five consecutive days. The primary outcome measure was the change in the Medical Research Council (MRC) sum score, which evaluates muscle strength in CIDP patients.

After the IVIG treatment, the MRC sum score significantly improved in 80% of the patients. The mean change in the MRC sum score was 3.5 points, indicating a clinically meaningful improvement in muscle strength. Adverse events were reported in 10% of patients, including mild infusion reactions and transient headaches.

In conclusion, IVIG treatment at a dose of 2 g/kg over five consecutive days appears to be an effective and well-tolerated therapy for patients with CIDP. Further prospective studies are needed to confirm these findings and determine the optimal dosing regimen for IVIG in CIDP.

Interventional radiologic alternatives to cholecystectomy. Cholecystectomy, or surgical removal of the gallbladder, is a commonly performed procedure for the treatment of gallbladder disease. However, in certain cases, interventional radiologic alternatives to cholecystectomy may be considered. These alternatives include percutaneous cholecystostomy, percutaneous transhepatic gallbladder drainage, and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with sphincterotomy and gallstone extraction. These procedures aim to address gallbladder disease while minimizing the need for surgical intervention and reducing patient morbidity. Percutaneous cholecystostomy involves the percutaneous insertion of a catheter into the gallbladder to drain bile and relieve symptoms. Percutaneous transhepatic gallbladder drainage involves inserting a needle into the gallbladder and placing a drainage catheter to bypass the obstruction. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with sphincterotomy and gallstone extraction allows for stone removal from the bile ducts without the need for surgical intervention. These interventional radiologic alternatives provide viable options for the management of gallbladder disease, particularly in patients who are not surgical candidates or have high surgical risks. Further research and evaluation are warranted to assess the long-term efficacy and safety of these interventions compared to traditional cholecystectomy.

Short-term memory and sentence comprehension. Previous studies have shown that short-term memory plays a crucial role in sentence comprehension. However, the underlying mechanisms and specific processes involved in this relationship remain unclear. In this study, we aimed to investigate the role of short-term memory in sentence comprehension and examine the extent to which different aspects of short-term memory, such as storage capacity and retrieval processes, contribute to sentence processing. We conducted a series of experiments utilizing a combination of behavioral and neuroimaging techniques to explore these questions. Our results suggest that short-term memory capacity is associated with sentence comprehension abilities, with individuals with higher short-term memory capacity exhibiting better sentence processing performance. Furthermore, our neuroimaging findings indicate that specific brain regions, such as the prefrontal cortex and hippocampus, are involved in both short-term memory and sentence comprehension processes. These findings provide important insights into the cognitive mechanisms underlying sentence comprehension and highlight the integral role of short-term memory in this complex process.

Primary osteosarcoma of the lung.  Report of two cases and review of the literature. Primary osteosarcoma of the lung is an extremely rare malignancy. We present two cases of primary osteosarcoma of the lung and provide a literature review on this topic. 

Case 1 involved a 46-year-old female with no previous history of malignancies, who presented with cough and hemoptysis. Imaging revealed a large mass in the left lower lobe, and pathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of osteosarcoma. The patient underwent surgical resection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and has been disease-free for 2 years.

Case 2 involved a 34-year-old male with a history of testicular seminoma treated with surgery and chemotherapy. He presented with dyspnea, and imaging showed multiple lung nodules. A biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of metastatic osteosarcoma. Despite undergoing chemotherapy and immunotherapy, the patient's disease progressed rapidly, and he succumbed to the disease within 6 months.

Based on our cases and a review of the literature, primary osteosarcoma of the lung typically presents as a large mass with nonspecific respiratory symptoms. Surgical resection, when feasible, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy appears to be the treatment of choice. Prognosis is generally poor due to the aggressive nature of this malignancy and the tendency for metastasis. Further studies are needed to better understand the pathogenesis, optimal treatment strategies, and prognosis of primary osteosarcoma of the lung.

Diphenylhydantoin-induced hypogammaglobulinemia in a patient infected with human immunodeficiency virus. We report a case of diphenylhydantoin (DPH)-induced hypogammaglobulinemia in a patient infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). The patient was being treated with DPH for seizures associated with AIDS-related central nervous system infection. Subsequently, the patient presented with recurrent bacterial infections and a significant decrease in serum immunoglobulin levels. After discontinuation of DPH, the immunoglobulin levels gradually returned to normal. This case highlights the potential immunomodulatory effects of DPH and the importance of considering drug-induced immunodeficiency in patients with HIV infection. Clinicians should be aware of this potential adverse effect and monitor the immunoglobulin levels in patients receiving DPH therapy, particularly in the setting of underlying immunodeficiency.

Pelvic pain: lessons from anatomy and physiology. Pelvic pain is a common complaint among women, and a comprehensive understanding of its underlying causes is essential for effective management. This review aims to explore the anatomical and physiological aspects of pelvic pain in order to provide a basis for improving diagnostic and therapeutic approaches. The complex anatomy of the pelvis involves multiple organs, including the uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, bladder, and rectum, which can all contribute to the sensation of pain. Additionally, hormonal fluctuations and the presence of nerve fibers in the pelvic region further contribute to the complex nature of pelvic pain. By gaining a deeper understanding of the anatomical and physiological factors involved, clinicians can develop tailored interventions and treatment strategies to alleviate pelvic pain and improve patients' quality of life.

Dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea: optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets. Acute childhood diarrhea is a common health issue in developing countries, including Kenya. This study aimed to evaluate the dietary management of acute childhood diarrhea, specifically focusing on the optimal timing of feeding and appropriate use of milks and mixed diets. A total of 200 children under 5 years of age with acute diarrhea were involved in a randomized controlled trial. The intervention group received early refeeding within 4 hours of admission, while the control group followed the conventional practice of delayed refeeding. Results showed that early refeeding significantly reduced the duration of diarrhea and hospital stay compared to delayed refeeding. Additionally, the use of milk-based diets and mixed diets was found to be safe and effective in promoting recovery. This study highlights the importance of timely feeding and appropriate dietary choices in managing acute childhood diarrhea, providing valuable insights for healthcare professionals and caregivers in developing countries.

Small bowel phytobezoar mimicking presentation of Crohn's disease. We present the case of a 34-year-old woman with a history of Crohn's disease who presented with symptoms of recurrent bowel obstruction. Abdominal imaging revealed a focal mass in the small bowel, and a diagnosis of Crohn's disease exacerbation was initially suspected. However, during surgical exploration, a phytobezoar was discovered as the cause of the obstruction. The patient had a history of chronic fruit and vegetable consumption, which likely contributed to the formation of the bezoar. This case highlights the importance of considering alternate diagnoses in patients with a known history of Crohn's disease presenting with symptoms suggestive of bowel obstruction. Awareness of phytobezoar as a potential mimicker of Crohn's disease can prevent unnecessary treatment and delay in surgical intervention.

Child care practices with respect to acute respiratory tract infection in a poor, urban community in Nigeria. In this study, we investigated child care practices related to acute respiratory tract infections (ARTIs) in a poor, urban community in Nigeria. A total of 150 caregivers were surveyed regarding their knowledge and practices surrounding ARTIs. The majority of caregivers (82%) were found to have poor knowledge about the cause, prevention, and treatment of ARTIs. Furthermore, only 45% of caregivers reported practicing proper hand hygiene techniques, such as washing hands with soap and water, to prevent the spread of infections. The use of traditional remedies and self-medication were common practices among caregivers. Additionally, overcrowding and lack of ventilation in households were prevalent in the community, increasing the risk of ARTIs. These findings highlight the need for targeted education and interventions to improve child care practices and reduce the burden of ARTIs in this vulnerable community.

Pathogenesis of antigen-induced arthritis in mice deficient in neutrophil elastase and cathepsin G. The pathogenesis of antigen-induced arthritis (AIA) in mice deficient in neutrophil elastase (NE) and cathepsin G (CG) was investigated. AIA is a well-established model for studying the pathophysiology of rheumatoid arthritis. NE and CG are serine proteases involved in inflammatory processes and have been implicated in the pathogenesis of arthritis. The study aimed to determine the role of NE and CG in AIA by comparing the inflammatory responses in wild-type mice and mice deficient in NE and CG. The results showed that NE and CG deficiency led to a significant reduction in joint swelling and histopathologic changes associated with AIA, indicating their importance in the development of arthritis. Furthermore, the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines was significantly decreased in NE and CG deficient mice compared to wild-type mice, suggesting that NE and CG play a critical role in the regulation of immune responses in AIA. In conclusion, the findings provide further evidence for the involvement of NE and CG in the pathogenesis of arthritis and may have implications for the development of therapeutic interventions targeting these proteases.

Prospective payment system and impairment at discharge. This study aimed to examine the relationship between the prospective payment system (PPS) and impairment at discharge in a population of stroke patients. A total of 126 patients with stroke were included, and their records were retrospectively analyzed. The patients were divided into two groups based on whether they were classified under the PPS or not. Impairment was assessed using the Modified Rankin Scale (MRS), with higher scores indicating greater disability. 

The results showed that patients classified under the PPS had significantly higher MRS scores at discharge compared to those not classified under the PPS. Additionally, patients under the PPS were more likely to have severe impairments (MRS score of 4 or 5) compared to those not under the PPS. Subgroup analysis revealed that this association was particularly pronounced in patients with a longer length of stay in the hospital.

These findings suggest that the PPS may be associated with higher levels of impairment at discharge in stroke patients. Further research is needed to explore the underlying factors contributing to this association and to develop strategies for optimizing patient outcomes under the PPS.

Flow cytometric DNA content of adenoid cystic carcinoma of submandibular gland.  Correlation of histologic features and prognosis. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) of the submandibular gland is a rare malignancy with a variable prognosis. The correlation between histologic features and prognosis in ACC remains unclear. In this study, flow cytometric DNA content analysis was performed on 32 cases of ACC of the submandibular gland to investigate the correlation between DNA ploidy and histologic features, as well as prognosis. Our results demonstrated that ACC with an aneuploid DNA content had a significantly higher rate of perineural invasion and lymph node metastasis compared to ACC with a diploid DNA content. Furthermore, patients with aneuploid ACC had a significantly shorter overall survival compared to patients with diploid ACC. These findings suggest that flow cytometric DNA content analysis can provide valuable information for predicting the behavior and prognosis of ACC of the submandibular gland.

Compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots. Compressive neuropathy of spinal nerve roots refers to a condition where the spinal nerve roots are compressed and subsequently injured, leading to neurological symptoms. This can occur due to various etiologies such as herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or tumor growth. The clinical presentation includes radicular pain, weakness, sensory deficits, and sometimes bladder or bowel dysfunction. Diagnostic tools including physical examination, imaging studies, and electrodiagnostic tests help identify the specific nerve roots affected and the underlying cause. Treatment options range from conservative management, such as physical therapy and analgesics, to surgical intervention for decompression or tumor removal. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are essential to alleviate symptoms, prevent further nerve damage, and improve patient outcomes. Further research is needed to optimize diagnostic strategies, refine treatment approaches, and enhance patient quality of life.

Prognostic significance of proteinuria one year after onset of diarrhea-associated hemolytic-uremic syndrome. Proteinuria is considered a prominent prognostic factor in patients with diarrhea-associated hemolytic-uremic syndrome (D+HUS). This study aimed to determine the prognostic significance of proteinuria one year after the onset of D+HUS. 
Data from 68 D+HUS patients were analyzed, and proteinuria levels were assessed at onset and one year after the initial presentation. Results showed that 80% of patients had proteinuria at onset, which decreased to 62% one year later. The median proteinuria levels also significantly decreased from 0.9 g/L at onset to 0.3 g/L after one year. 
Furthermore, patients with persistent proteinuria at one year had a higher risk of renal impairment, hypertension, and abnormal renal ultrasounds. This suggests that proteinuria at one year after D+HUS onset could be an indicator of long-term renal prognosis. Therefore, regular monitoring of proteinuria levels one year after D+HUS is essential for identifying patients at higher risk of chronic renal complications.

Vaginal epithelial abnormalities in patients with CIN: clinical and pathological features and management. Vaginal epithelial abnormalities are commonly observed in patients with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). However, there is limited research addressing the clinical and pathological features of these abnormalities and their optimal management. This study aimed to evaluate the characteristics of vaginal epithelial abnormalities in patients with CIN and propose an appropriate management strategy. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 185 patients diagnosed with CIN, and their medical records were reviewed for clinical and pathological data. Vaginal epithelial abnormalities were observed in 55% of the patients, with 30% showing atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASCUS) and 25% exhibiting low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL). Further analysis revealed that the presence of abnormal vaginal epithelium was significantly associated with higher CIN grades and positive high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) status. Consequently, a comprehensive management approach that includes close follow-up and risk factor modification should be implemented for patients with CIN and concurrent vaginal epithelial abnormalities to ensure early detection and appropriate intervention.

Effect of exposure of miners to aluminium powder. Exposure to aluminum powder in miners has been associated with various health effects, including respiratory problems, neurological disorders, and a potential increase in the risk of developing lung cancer. However, the specific mechanisms underlying these effects remain unclear. In this study, we aimed to investigate the effect of aluminum powder exposure on miners and its potential health implications. A total of 200 miners were recruited from a mining site and were categorized into two groups based on their duration and intensity of exposure to aluminum powder. Various health parameters, including respiratory function, neurological status, and cancer risk, were assessed and compared between the two groups. Preliminary results indicate a significant decline in respiratory function and an increased prevalence of neurological disorders in miners exposed to higher levels of aluminum powder. Additionally, initial data suggest an elevated risk of developing lung cancer in miners with prolonged exposure to aluminum powder. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanisms and establish effective preventive measures for aluminum powder-induced health effects in miners.
